--- title: "3.1 — Dynamic Games and Collusion — Class Content" execute: freeze: auto --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.callout-note appearance=minimal} # Meeting Date *Tuesday, March 7, 2023* ::: ## Overview Today we extend our understanding of game theory to talk about how collusion can be sustainable. ## Readings - Ch. 7, 9, 10 in [Church & Ware, 2000](https://works.bepress.com/jeffrey_church/23/) ### Recommended/Referenced Readings - [ Stigler, 1964, “A Theory of Oligopoly”](/files/readings/Stigler-1964.pdf) Chapter 7 is a good overview of static game theory - read it if you have not yet, or want some more of the basics. We will focus simply on Nash equilibrium and the possibility of multiple Nash equilibria. Chapter 9 is a good overview of sequential games and repeated games, which we will introduce today. Chapter 10 discusses oligopoly in light of how collusion can be sustained in dynamic settings. ## Slides Below, you can find the slides in two formats. Clicking the image will bring you to the html version of the slides in a new tab. The lower button will allow you to download a PDF version of the slides. ::: callout-tip You can type h to see a special list of viewing options, and type o for an outline view of all the slides. ::: I suggest printing the slides beforehand and using them to take additional notes in class (*not everything* is in the slides)!

Download as PDF
